article.headline: Krauser has nine points, nine assists, seven boards
article.linkText: Pitt's N.Y. players exact revenge on St. John's
article.story: PITTSBURGH (AP) -- Carl Krauser made sure St. John's regretted its decision not to recruit him. Krauser, who grew up in the Bronx, led No. 4 Pittsburgh to a 71-51 victory Tuesday night, the Panthers' school-record 17th home win of the season. Krauser had nine points, nine assists and seven rebounds for the Panthers (21-1, 7-1 Big East), who are off to their best start ever in the conference. "I wanted to show St. John's the little magic that they were missing," Krauser said. Many of Krauser's passes found their way into the hands of Pitt's forwards. Chris Taft, another player who came to Pitt from New York, led the Panthers with 15 points. Jaron Brown scored 13, and Chevon Troutman added 11. Taft had four dunks, while Toree Morris and Mark McCarroll had two each. Pitt had 24 points on the fast break, 20 more than St. John's. "I like seeing the big guys run the floor and dunk more than I do scoring," Krauser said. "It's fun when we play that way." The Panthers won their 39th consecutive home game and are 33-0 at the Petersen Events Center. "They do everything right," St. John's coach Kevin Clark said. "They pound the ball inside physically, they pass the ball and they run well. They play together." Pitt coach Jamie Dixon was more concerned about the team's upcoming road stretch than the Panthers' success at home. Pitt plays at Notre Dame and Seton Hall in a three-day stretch. "It seems like we're always talking about a tough stretch that's coming up," Dixon said. "That's part of being in the Big East. We've already been through a few and we have one coming up. But our guys love challenges." The Panthers, who have held 15 of their 22 opponents to under 60 points, forced the Red Storm to commit 18 turnovers. "I was surprised to see them back down and not play a 40-minute game," Krauser said. St. John's (5-14, 0-8) is off to its worst start in Big East play and is 3-10 under Clark, who replaced Mike Jarvis on Dec. 19. The Red Storm were coming off a 71-55 win over UCLA that snapped a seven-game losing streak. Clark admitted his team was no match for the Panthers. "They hit us with some haymakers and it took us a while to get off the canvas," he said. Darryll Hill led the Red Storm with 16 points. Elijah Ingram scored all 11 of his points in the second half. Ingram, who scored 21 points against UCLA and was second in the Big East in 3-pointers, broke his nose in practice Tuesday and wore a face shield to cover his injury. He was 4-of-14 from the floor, including 3-of-9 from from 3-point range. He also committed a game-high five turnovers. Troutman scored nine of his points in the first half as Pitt, which was coming off a week layoff, opened a 38-19 lead. "We wanted to make sure we came out aggressive and jumped on them," McCarroll said. St. John's had won seven of the previous eight meetings between the two schools.
